awd_titl_txt: CRII: CNS: Security Assessment of Spectrum Coexistence in Co-located Heterogeneous Wireless IoT Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Today’s advancement in wireless access to telecommunication networks (e.g., Internet) is attributed to Marconi’s century-old radio design, where the radio spectrum is divided into pieces and given to different wireless technologies/entities. Though it worked for the most part of the last decade, this strategy has become a bottleneck and unable to accommodate future growth in wireless communications, especially with the introduction of Internet-of-Things (IoT). The exponentially increasing radio spectrum demand has forced us to forge new paths to improve spectrum utilization, such as network densification and coexistence among heterogeneous IoT networks on the same channel. Nonetheless, the synergy of network densification and spectrum sharing will increase the co-channel interference and lead to more complex inter-technology interactions, which require well-designed spectrum sharing mechanisms. However, designing such mechanisms is not trivial - not only due to technical aspects but also due to added security vulnerabilities. The introduction of shared spectrum access in a dense scenario drastically changes the balance among lower layers (i.e., PHY and MAC) and compels a radical change in the security protocol design. This project introduces a novel security vulnerability in coexistence among co-located heterogeneous IoT devices (e.g., LTE, Wi-Fi) and aims to develop security mechanisms to counteract the proposed attack. The project aims to ensure a fair and secure coexistence on the spectrum, contributing to the growth of future wireless technologies in many more centuries to come. In addition, this project will provide the students at Towson University with resources to pursue network security research at the undergraduate and graduate levels.

This project concentrates on the unique security weaknesses created from the dense use of a shared spectrum between co-located heterogeneous IoT networks. The proposed research will take a multi-pronged approach by: (1) developing formal models based on PHY and MAC layer attributes to understand how attackers may exploit the shared spectrum access among heterogeneous networks, (2) designing a Markov decision process-based novel safeguard strategy to circumvent such attacks, and (3) developing a software-defined testbed to materialize the proposed approaches. This research will lay the groundwork for upcoming system research on spectrum coexistence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the Internet-of-Things (IoT) technology, a growing number of physical objects of everyday life can be connected to the Internet. IoT technology enables these objects to communicate, share information, and collaborate directly without human involvement to deliver a new class of applications and services. Much research has addressed various IoT issues, including service discovery, routing, security and privacy, availability, reliability, mobility, performance assessment, management, scalability, and interoperability. Many standards are also proposed to provide application protocols in support of the IoT. 

However, realizing IoT ambition requires numerous wireless IoT devices deployed in a small physical space, and they may follow different wireless technologies, such as cellular, Wi-Fi, and Zigbee. Therefore, IoT has triggered competition for radio resources, likely creating unique interference challenges. Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has been trying to manage this competition by 1) increasing the available unlicensed spectrum (e.g., opening up the 6 GHz band) and 2) increasing spectrum utilization by fostering coexistence (e.g., LTE and Wi-Fi coexistence on the 5GHz unlicensed spectrum and three-tiered access in the 3.5 GHz Citizens Broadband Radio Service (CBRS) band. This research, however, argues that spectrum coexistence will create new security challenges. Although security in standalone IoT has been addressed extensively, security in coexistent IoT networks with a shared spectrum is under-explored. The adoption of shared spectrum access significantly changes the lower layers' dynamics, and it compels a radical rethinking of the security protocol design.

This proposal aimed to design, analyze, and evaluate new security and privacy algorithms for protecting densely deployed Internet of Things (IoT) networks coexisting in a small physical space. Unlike existing IoT security research, this proposed study addressed the unique security challenges in spectrum sharing between 3GPP and Wi-Fi. The proposed designs aimed to enhance effective spectrum utilization and the coexistence of IoT networks by detecting and defending against specific attacks during spectrum sharing while also offering secure and efficient machine learning models to assist in such detection and defense. The approach involved identifying the unique vulnerabilities in coexistent 3GPP and Wi-Fi networks, formulating and deducing the behaviors of attacks that exploited these vulnerabilities, and intelligently utilizing the deduced characteristics of these attacks to maximize the advantages of the security design.

This research systematically addressed the unique security issues of spectrum coexistence between two wireless technologies, LTE/NR-Unlicensed and Wi-Fi, in the 5GHz band. In particular, it completed three major research tasks to compose the novel spectrum coexistence security challenges: (1) discovered a novel attack strategy for a malicious or rogue Wi-Fi AP that could exploit the design vulnerability of the gap-based mechanism utilized by the LTE/NR-Unlicensed while coexisting with Wi-Fi in the 5GHz spectrum band; (2) developed a Discrete Time Markov Chain model (DTMC) to study the impact of such an attack and demonstrated the effect on LTE/NR-Unlicensed performance in terms of channel occupancy and throughput; (3) developed a resilience strategy that potentially rendered cellular devices more adaptable to such threats and integrated the framework in the DTMC model of the LTE/NR-Unlicensed transmission cycle.

This research is potentially transformative as it helped generate innovative and secure spectrum-sharing techniques for numerous applications, such as smart cities, smart homes, and mobile health. It also significantly impacted research in emerging technologies with dynamic spectrum access, such as intelligent transportation systems and public safety networks.

This project has provided excellent opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate research students to gain valuable training and experience. A PhD student and four undergraduates participated in the research, and the resulting findings were presented at prestigious IEEE conferences. Topics related to spectrum coexistence were also integrated into graduate-level courses at George Mason University and Towson University. This integration created a beneficial synergy between the course content and the research outcomes.
